James did not play at the 2010 FIBA World Championship but rejoined Team USA for the 2012 Olympics in London, England.[407] He became the leader of the team, with Bryant, who would soon be 34, stepping back.[408] James facilitated the offense from the post and perimeter, called the defensive sets, and provided scoring when needed.[409] During a game against Australia, he recorded the first triple-double in U.S. Olympic basketball history with 11 points, 14 rebounds, and 12 assists.[d] Team USA went on to win their second straight gold medal, again defeating Spain in the final game.[411] James contributed 19 points in the victory, becoming the all-time leading scorer in U.S. men's basketball history.[395][411] He also joined Michael Jordan as the only players to win an NBA MVP award, NBA championship, NBA Finals MVP, and Olympic gold medal in the same year.[412] Afterwards, Krzyzewski said: "[James] is the best player, he is the best leader and he is as smart as anybody playing the game right now."[413]

After a 12-year gap, James rejoined the national team on the 2024 Olympic squad in Paris as Team Captain at 39 years old.[414] Voted by the entire 592-strong U.S. delegation, James was named as one of the two Team USA flag-bearers for the opening ceremony of the games, becoming the first male basketball player to be so honored.[415][416] James led the team in rebounds and assists. He recorded his second Olympic triple double in a comeback win in the semi-final against Serbia with 16 points, 12 rebounds and 10 assists.[417] James became the first player in Olympic history with two triple doubles.[418] Team USA went on to win their fifth straight gold medal, defeating France 98–87 in the final game,[419] with James recording 14 points, 6 rebounds and 10 assists. At the conclusion of the tournament with averages of 14.2 points, 6.8 rebounds and 8.5 assists, James was named the FIBA Men's Olympics MVP and was selected to the FIBA Men's Olympics All-Star Five.[420] James became the third male basketball player to win three gold medals at the Olympics.

Player profile
Standing 6 feet 9 inches (2.06 m) tall and weighing 250 pounds (113 kg),[421] James has played the majority of his career at the small forward and power forward positions,[5] but he has also been deployed at the other positions when necessary.[422] His playing style, which is athletic and versatile,[134] has drawn comparisons to Basketball Hall of Famers Oscar Robertson, Magic Johnson, and Michael Jordan.[423][424][425] Through the 2023–24 season, James' career averages are 27.1 points, 7.5 rebounds, 7.4 assists, 1.5 steals, and 0.7 blocks per game.[5] Throughout the 2010s, he was usually ranked as the best player in the NBA each season by ESPN and Sports Illustrated.[426][427]

Offense
As an 18-year-old rookie, James led the Cavaliers in scoring.[429] He holds numerous "youngest to" distinctions,[430][431] including being the youngest player to score 30,000 career points.[432] During his first stint in Cleveland, James was primarily used as an on-ball point forward, and although his shooting tendencies were perimeter-oriented,[134] he established himself as one of the best slashers and finishers in basketball.[433][434] His combination of speed, quickness, and size often created matchup problems for opposing teams because James was capable of blowing by larger defenders and overpowering smaller ones.[435] These qualities became more apparent in transition, where he developed a reputation for grabbing defensive rebounds and then beating the defense downcourt for highlight reel baskets.[436] Around this time, James was frequently criticized for not having a reliable jump shot or post game.[437] Teams would try to exploit these weaknesses by giving him space in the half court and forcing him to settle for three-pointers and long two-pointers, a strategy famously used by Spurs coach Gregg Popovich in the 2007 Finals, where James converted on only 36 percent of his field goals in four games.[438]

In Miami, Heat coach Erik Spoelstra changed James' role to a more unconventional one.[134] James spent more time in the post and improved his shot selection and accuracy on jump shots.[134][439] He also learned how to work as an off-ball cutter in the Heat's "pass-happy" offense.[440] Behind these improvements, James' overall scoring efficiency rose to historically great levels.[441] During this time, ESPN's Tom Haberstroh called James's free-throw shooting his biggest weakness, describing it as "average".[442] Upon returning to the Cavaliers, James began to experience subtle age-related declines in productivity,[443] posting his lowest scoring averages since his rookie season in 2015 and 2016.[5][444] His shooting also temporarily regressed, and James briefly ranked as the NBA's worst high-volume shooter from outside the paint.[445] Despite these changes, he remained an elite offensive player who beat defenses with body control, strength, and varying attacking speeds.[435]

For most of his career, James has controlled the offense as the primary ball handler on his team.[446] His playmaking ability is generally considered one of his premier skills, and some analysts rank him among the greatest passers in NBA history.[447] By exploiting his size, vision, and the attention James garners from opposing defenses,[448] he creates easy points for his teammates with accurate assists.[449] James executes unconventional passes, including after leaving his feet and through defensive traffic.[450] His uncanny tendency to find the open man has helped force NBA teams to incorporate some elements of zone into their schemes to better cover the weak side of the court and prevent James from passing to open shooters.[435] Early in his career, James was criticized for overpassing in pressure situations, in particular for passing instead of shooting in the waning seconds of close games;[451][452] however, as his career progressed, James' clutch performance was viewed more favorably.[453]

Defense
At the beginning of his NBA career, James was considered a poor defensive player,[454] but he improved steadily through the years. In 2009, James became proficient at the chase-down block, which involves coming in from behind the opposition in transition to block the shot.[75] In Miami, he developed into a more versatile defensive player, and the Heat relied on him to guard all five positions.[455] From the years 2012–2016, he was ranked among the top three defenders in the NBA by general managers, earning the vote as the best perimeter defender in the league preceding the 2014–15 NBA season.[456] Along with Shane Battier and Dwyane Wade, Miami used James in an ultra-aggressive defensive scheme,[457] with James cheating off the ball to help out inside or get into rebounding position.[458] Beginning in 2014, some analysts reported a regression in his defensive impact, stemming from a lack of effort and expected age-related declines.[459][460] During his second stint in Cleveland, James' defense progressively declined. After missed drives on offense, he often dawdled back on defense while complaining to the referees; he provided less help off the ball, and was less aggressive in switching.[461] James himself admitted to taking plays off at times, referring to this approach as "chill mode".[462] He eventually developed a reputation for raising his defensive level in the playoffs, which some analysts referred to as "Playoff LeBron".[463]

Legacy
James left high school as one of the most hyped prospects in NBA history.[e] Upon entering the NBA, he made an immediate impact and was voted Rookie of the Year in his debut season.[469] As of 2024, James has been named to 20 All-NBA Teams, including 13 times to the First Team, which are both NBA records.[3] His four MVP awards are matched only by Michael Jordan, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Wilt Chamberlain, and Bill Russell; James and Russell are the only players to win four MVP awards in a five-year span.[470] James has also won four Finals MVP Awards, which is the second-most all-time,[471] and earned All-Defensive honors every season from 2009 to 2014.[5] While James has never won the Defensive Player of the Year Award, he has finished second in the voting twice and lists it as one of his main goals.[74][472] His teams have appeared in the Finals ten times and won four championships; his 10 Finals appearances are tied for third all-time.[f] Some analysts have criticized him for not having a better Finals record, while others have countered that James usually performed well but his team was defeated by superior competition.[474][475][476]

On the basis of his career longevity and on-court performances, sports publications have consistently included James in rankings of the best basketball players in history,[g] and he was named the Associated Press Male Athlete of the Decade for the 2010s.[484] This has resulted in frequent comparisons to Michael Jordan.[a] In a 2016 interview with Sports Illustrated, James acknowledged that his motivation was surpassing Jordan as the greatest.[485] In February 2018, The Ringer spent an entire week devoted to both players, with Bill Simmons ultimately concluding that Jordan was still ahead.[486] In polls, James has ranked second behind Jordan.[487][488][489] The results strongly correlate with age, with older voters more commonly choosing Jordan.[488][489] Davis et al. of Business Insider stated: "The data would suggest that younger, more-engaged NBA fans lean toward James, as he's still playing. Older generations who watched Jordan play and tune in less today lean toward Jordan."[489] Referring to James as the best challenger to Jordan's status as the greatest basketball player of all time, Sam Quinn of CBS Sports stated that "the margin for error where Jordan is involved is overwhelmingly slim" and that "in the rings-obsessed basketball discourse", Jordan having more titles and an "unblemished Finals record holds significant weight".[485]

In addition to praising James' on-court accomplishments, analysts have also noted his influence on player empowerment throughout the NBA, which stemmed from his willingness to change teams during free agency. Ben Golliver of The Washington Post opined that James' move to the Heat in 2010 "defined a decade of player movement", and that he "fundamentally flipped the power balance between stars and their organizations."[490] James' fellow players have also remarked on his influence, such as Warriors forward Draymond Green, who reflected: "We've taken control of our destiny. And I think a lot of people hate that ... I think the doors that he's opened for athletes and especially basketball players is his biggest accomplishment."[491] Multiple current and former NBA players have suggested James' free agency decisions catalyzed the leaguewide trend in "superteams" in the 21st century.[492][493][494][495][496]

In 2022, James voiced his desire to play into his forties potentially alongside or against his sons Bronny and Bryce.[497] This eventually happened when Bronny was selected by the Lakers 55th overall in the 2024 NBA draft, making them the first father-son duo in NBA history.[498]

Personal life
James married his high school sweetheart, Savannah James, on September 14, 2013, in San Diego, California.[499] They have three children: sons Bronny and Bryce, and daughter Zhuri.[497][500] Bronny was a standout high school basketball player, being named a McDonald's All-American in 2023, 20 years after James's selection.[501] During his stint with the Heat, James resided in Coconut Grove, where he bought a $9 million three-story mansion overlooking Biscayne Bay.[502] In November 2015, James bought a 9,350 square-foot (870 m2) East Coast-style mansion in Brentwood, Los Angeles, for about $21 million.[503] He purchased another home in Brentwood in December 2017 for $23 million.[504] In September 2020, he purchased a third home in Los Angeles, this one in Beverly Hills for $36.75 million.[505] James also owns a 30,000 square foot mansion in Akron, Ohio that he custom built in 2003 on his property and spent $2.1 million on it.[506]

James's best friends in the NBA are Carmelo Anthony, Chris Paul, and former Heat teammate Dwyane Wade. The four have been referred to as the "banana boat crew". During an excursion to the Bahamas, James rescued Anthony from the water when Anthony was carried away from the boat by the current. During an Instagram Live session, Anthony later recounted: "He saved my life". When asked about how much danger Anthony was in prior to the rescue, James responded: "I don't really know what to say, to be honest. I'm just happy he's still here, obviously."[507] James also maintains a friendship with fellow NBA player Draymond Green.[508]

In September 2023, ESPN reported that a new set of client names from the Biogenesis scandal had been released; included was Ernest "Randy" Mims, a longtime friend and business manager of James, as well as David Alexander, a well-known trainer of prominent athletes who co-owned a cold-pressed juice and smoothie business with Savannah and also served as her personal trainer. The DEA determined that there "was never any indication that LeBron James did anything wrong."[509][510]

Health
James invests heavily in his health, reportedly spending $1.5 million a year to pay for personal chefs, athletic trainers, and physical therapies for recovery. Kyle Korver has described James's fitness as being on "another level". However, James' routine is not perfectly clean; he drinks wine every night, falsely believing it to be good for his heart,[511] while Tristan Thompson has stated that James eats desserts with every meal.[512]

In January 2009, doctors at the Cleveland Clinic discovered a growth in the right side of James's jaw. Biopsy results showed that James developed a benign jaw tumor, specifically in his parotid gland,[513] which required a five-hour surgery to remove on June 2 after the end of the Cavaliers' run in the 2009 playoffs.[514]

Public image
James is considered by fellow NBA players, media tabloids, and popular culture to be the "face of the NBA", often alongside Warriors superstar Stephen Curry.[515][516] His opinions have yielded significant influence on people who make important league decisions; for example, in 2014, James asked commissioner Adam Silver to increase the duration of the All-Star break, and the request was granted the following season.[517] On February 13, 2015, James was elected the first vice president of the National Basketball Players Association (NBPA).[518]

Throughout his career, James has been ranked by Forbes as one of the world's most influential athletes,[h] and has been listed by Time as one of the 100 most influential people in the world.[521] During his first stint with the Cavaliers, James was adored by local fans, and Sherwin-Williams displayed a giant Nike-produced banner of James on its world headquarters.[522] Despite their affection for James, Cleveland fans and critics were frequently annoyed when he sported a Yankees hat when he attended Cleveland Indians baseball games against the New York Yankees.[523] Following his actions during the 2010 free agency period and The Decision, James was listed as one of the most disliked athletes in the United States.[524] By 2013, his image had mostly recovered and he was reported by ESPN as the most popular player in the NBA for the second time in his career.[525] In 2014, James was named the most popular male athlete in America by the Harris Poll.[526] He has led the league in jersey sales six times.[527]



Memorabilia associated with James is highly sought after; two of James' rookie cards are among the most expensive basketball cards ever sold at auction, and one of those cards also briefly held the record for the most expensive modern-day sports card when it sold for $1.8 million at auction in July 2020.[530] A Mike Trout rookie card broke the record for a modern-day card the following month.[531] All jerseys worn in the 2020 NBA All-Star Game were auctioned by the NBA and NBPA to raise funds for charity; James' jersey sold for $630,000, setting a record for a modern-day sports jersey.[532]

In March 2008, James became the first black man, as well as the third man overall after Richard Gere and George Clooney, to appear on the cover of Vogue, when he posed with Gisele Bündchen.[533] In response, ESPN columnist Jemele Hill considered the cover offensive and "memorable for the wrong reasons", describing the demeanor of James and his holding Bündchen as a reference to classic imagery of the movie monster King Kong, a dark savage capturing his fair-skinned love interest.[528][529]

Activism
Philanthropy
James has maintained close ties to his hometown of Akron, Ohio, which is also where his charity foundation, the LeBron James Family Foundation (LJFF), is based.[534] Since 2005, the foundation has held an annual bike-a-thon to raise money for various causes.[535] In 2015, James announced a partnership with the University of Akron to provide scholarships for as many as 2,300 children beginning in 2021.[536] In 2017, he received the J. Walter Kennedy Citizenship Award from the NBA for his "outstanding service and dedication to the community."[537]

In November 2017, the Akron School Board approved the I Promise School, a public elementary school created in a partnership with the LJFF to help struggling elementary school students stay in school.[538] The school officially opened on July 30, 2018, with James reflecting that it was his most important professional accomplishment.[539] Other noteworthy public and charitable initiatives undertaken by James in Akron include the I Promise Institute at the University of Akron,[540] I Promise Village (housing complex),[541] House Three-Thirty (community center/retail plaza),[542] and I Promise Health Quarters (medical center).[15]

James is also an active supporter of various non-profit organizations, including After-School All-Stars, Boys & Girls Clubs of America, and Children's Defense Fund.[543][544][545] In 2016, he donated $2.5 million to the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture to support an exhibit on Muhammad Ali.[546]

Politics
Throughout his career, James has taken public stances on controversial issues, and has mentioned a feeling of obligation to effect change using his status.[547] Those include the War in Darfur,[548] the killing of Trayvon Martin,[549] the now-former NBA owner Donald Sterling's racist comments in 2014,[547] the Michael Brown verdict,[550] the death of Eric Garner,[551] the U.S. national anthem kneeling protests,[552] the shooting of Breonna Taylor,[553] the death of Ma'Khia Bryant,[554] Kyle Rittenhouse,[555] and the ruling of Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization that overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022.[556]

On August 27, 2020, James and his Lakers teammates, as well as the Bucks, began boycotting the 2020 NBA playoffs to protest the shooting of Jacob Blake.[557] In response, senior White House advisor Jared Kushner stated that he was planning to reach out to James regarding the boycott. Following a players' committee to discuss the boycott, James and others reached out to former president Barack Obama, who reportedly advised them to continue playing and finish that year's NBA season.[558]

During the 2019–2020 Hong Kong protests, a statement James made about a since-deleted tweet by Daryl Morey,[559] in which Morey expressed support for the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong, became the subject of controversy. James said Morey was "misinformed".[560] His statement drew backlash from protesters in the movement, with some taking to social media to use racist language against him.[561][562][563] In February 2022, political commentator Bill Maher called James hypocritical for not taking a critical stance towards the Chinese government's human rights abuses.[564] James had taken various other stands on issues regarding sports, such as the Kaepernick controversy and the Houston Astros sign stealing scandal.[565][566]

In October 2023, in response to the 2023 Israel–Hamas war, James voiced his support for Israel on Instagram.[567] His statement drew backlash for its omission of the Palestinians affected by the crisis, including from Palestinian-American leader and activist Omar Suleiman.[568][569][570]

In June 2008, James donated $20,000 to a committee in support of Barack Obama for the 2008 U.S. presidential election.[571] Later that year, James gathered almost 20,000 people at the then-called Quicken Loans Arena for a viewing of Obama's 30-minute American Stories, American Solutions television advertisement.[572] The advertisement was shown on a large screen above the stage, where Jay-Z later held a free concert.[572] In November 2016, James endorsed and campaigned for Hillary Clinton for the 2016 U.S. presidential election.[573]

Following a racist incident at his Los Angeles home in 2017, James expressed that "being black in America is tough. We got a long way to go for us as a society and for us as African Americans until we feel equal in America."[574] Later on that year, in the aftermath of the Unite the Right rally, James questioned the "Make America Great Again" slogan and said: "It's sad what's going on in Charlottesville. Is this the direction our country is heading? Make America Great Again huh? Our youth deserve better!!"[575] James also called President Donald Trump a "bum" after the president rescinded a White House invitation to Stephen Curry.[576] During a 2018 interview with CNN journalist Don Lemon, James then accused Trump of attempting to divide the country with sports, suggesting that "sports has never been something that divides people it's always been something that brings someone together." He declared that he would "never sit across from him. I'd sit across from Obama though."[577][578] In response, Trump tweeted: "LeBron James was just interviewed by the dumbest man on television, Don Lemon. He made LeBron look smart, which isn't easy to do."[579]

On August 19, 2020, James announced his intentions to support the Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign and that of his running-mate Kamala Harris in advance of the 2020 U.S. presidential election.[580] James spoke in support of the More Than a Vote movement and encouraged members of the African-American community to vote,[581] saying, "People in our community have been just lied to for so many years. We have people that have had convictions in the past, that've been told they cannot vote because they got a conviction. That is voter suppression."[582]

On October 31, 2024, James announced his support for the Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign in the 2024 U.S. presidential election.[583]

Media figure and business interests
According to Forbes, in May 2023, James became the first active NBA player to become a billionaire,[584] making him one of the richest celebrities.

James' biography LeBron was published on April 11, 2023, by Jeff Benedict. The biography is based on three years of research and more than 250 interviews.[585]

Endorsements
James has signed numerous endorsement contracts; some of the companies that he has done business with are AT&T,[586] Audemars Piguet,[587] Beats by Dre,[588] Blaze Pizza,[589] Coca-Cola,[590] Dunkin' Brands,[591] Intel,[592] Kia,[593] McDonald's,[594] Nike,[590]PepsiCo,[595] State Farm,[596] and Taco Bell.[597] Coming out of high school, James was the target of a three-way bidding war among Nike, Reebok, and Adidas,[598] eventually signing a seven-year deal with Nike in 2003[599] for approximately $90 million.[600] His signature shoes have performed well for Nike.[601] In 2011, Fenway Sports Group became the sole global marketer of his rights, and as part of the deal, James was granted a minority stake in the English Premier League football club Liverpool,[602] who he has claimed his support for.[603] As a result of his endorsement money and NBA salary, James has been listed as one of the world's highest-paid athletes.[604] In 2013, he surpassed Bryant as the highest paid basketball player in the world, with earnings of $56.5 million.[605] In 2014, James realized a profit of more than $30 million as part of Apple's acquisition of Beats Electronics; he had originally struck a deal to get a small stake in the company at its inception in exchange for promoting its headphones.[606] In 2015, James was ranked the sixth highest earning sportsperson,[607] and third highest in 2016 (after Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi).[608] James has stated that he would like to own an NBA team in the future, albeit in a hands-off capacity.[609] In 2011, James co-founded the designer retail store UNKNWN in Miami, Florida.[610]

During Super Bowl LVI in 2022, James appeared in a Crypto.com advertisement, where he conversed with a CGI version of his younger self, offering advice about the future. The commercial, produced by James' SpringHill Company and directed by Calmatic, did not directly promote the service, sparked social media buzz, and inspired a series of memes centered on the advice he could have offered.[611]

Subsequently, Crypto.com launched an NFT airdrop campaign, distributing 5,550 tokens featuring the NBA champion. Participants were chosen randomly from those who scanned a QR code in the Super Bowl ad.[612] Also, in 2022, James' charity LeBron James Family Foundation, partnered with Crypto.com to educate underserved Akron communities with blockchain-related knowledge and Web3 tools, aiming to ensure inclusive advancement in the digital age.[613][614]

Entertainment
James and comedian Jimmy Kimmel co-hosted the 2007 ESPY Awards.[615] In other comedic pursuits, he hosted the 33rd-season premiere of Saturday Night Live.[616] James has also tried his hand at acting, appearing in a cameo role on the HBO series Entourage.[617] In 2015, he played himself in the Judd Apatow film Trainwreck,[618] receiving positive reviews for his performance.[619] That same year, James' digital video company Uninterrupted raised $15.8 million from Warner Bros. Entertainment and Turner Sports to help expand the company's efforts to bring athlete-created content to fans. It is hosted on Bleacher Report and is used by several other athletes including Tampa Bay Buccaneers tight end Rob Gronkowski and cornerback Richard Sherman.[620]

James and his business partner Maverick Carter own production company SpringHill Entertainment,[621] whose first work was the Lions Gate documentary More Than a Game, which was released in 2009 and chronicled James' high school years.[622] Series produced by SpringHill include the NBC game show The Wall,[623] the Disney XD sports documentary show Becoming,[624] the Starz sitcom Survivor's Remorse,[625] and the animated web series The LeBrons.[626] In 2016, CNBC aired an unscripted series hosted by James called Cleveland Hustles, where four up-and-coming Northern Ohio entrepreneurs will be financed on the condition of revitalizing a neighborhood in Cleveland.[627] In the 2017 Toronto International Film Festival, a 60-minute Vince Carter documentary entitled The Carter Effect was executive produced by James and Maverick Carter along with rapper Drake and Future the Prince.[628][629] In February 2018, it was announced that James' production company will produce a new film in the House Party series with James expected to make a cameo.[630] Later that month, Fox News host Laura Ingraham told James to "shut up and dribble" as a response to his political agendas.[631] This largely contributed to James creating a documentary film series looking at the changing role of athletes in the current political and cultural climate, aptly named, Shut Up and Dribble on Showtime.[632] James partnered with Arnold Schwarzenegger in 2018 to found Ladder, a company that developed nutritional supplements to help athletes with severe cramps after dealing with that issue during the 2014 Finals.[633]

In February 2019, it was revealed that James would executive produce rapper 2 Chainz's new album Rap or Go to the League.[634] A Def Jam press release said the intent of the album is "celebrating black excellence and focusing on the power of education and entrepreneurship." The press release also says the title "challenges the notion that the only way out of the inner city is either to become a rapper or a ball player."[635] As of June 2023, James is the most followed basketball player on Instagram, with over 155 million followers.[636]

In June 2022, it was announced James was launching a media company in partnership with professional tennis player Naomi Osaka and Maverick Carter. The production and content creation company will be named Hana Kuma, which means "flower" and "bear" in Japanese.[637]

In March 2024, James and JJ Redick launched a podcast called Mind the Game, where the two have "pure conversations about basketball."[638][639][640]

Investments
In 2012, James, Carter and Paul Wachter made an investment of less than $1 million in the Pasadena-based fast casual chain Blaze Pizza; their investment had grown to $25 million by 2017.[641] James later became a spokesman for the company and began appearing in advertisements after ending his contract with McDonald's.[641]

During the 2019 offseason, James filed for a trademark through a shell company on the term "Taco Tuesday" for use in downloadable audio/visual works, podcasts, social media, online marketing, and entertainment services.[642] This was related to James's use of the term on Instagram for his family's taco dinners. The request was denied by the United States Patent and Trademark Office, stating that Taco Tuesday was "a commonplace term, message or expression widely used by a variety of sources that merely conveys an ordinary, familiar, well-recognized concept or sentiment."[643]

In November 2020, James became an angel investor of the tequila and mezcal company Lobos 1707.[644] After personal frustration with comments on the Black Lives Matter movement made by Republican U.S. senator Kelly Loeffler, who at the time was the owner of the WNBA's Atlanta Dream, James assisted Dream player Renee Montgomery in her ultimately successful bid to buy the team in March 2021.[645] That same year, James joined Fenway Sports Group as a partner, making him a part-owner of the Boston Red Sox, New England Sports Network, RFK Racing, and Liverpool F.C., the latter of which he already owned a two-percent share in individually.[646] The investment made James and Carter the company's first black partners.[646]

James has expressed his interest in owning an NBA team once he finishes playing basketball, specifically a team located in Las Vegas, Nevada, either through expansion or relocation.[647]

In August 2022, James, alongside Canadian musician Drake, became part owners of the Italian football club A.C. Milan.[648]

James is also a part owner of the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League (NHL).[649]

Professional contracts
James is represented by agent Rich Paul of Klutch Sports.[650] His first agent was Aaron Goodwin, whom he left in 2005 for Leon Rose. Rose joined Creative Artists Agency (CAA) in 2007, and he worked with fellow CAA agent Henry Thomas, who represented Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh, to bring James to Miami in 2010. James left CAA for Paul in 2012.[651] James, Paul, Maverick Carter, and Randy Mims—all childhood friends—formed agent and sports-marketing company LRMR after James left Goodwin. LRMR handles James's marketing, including the marketing of The Decision, for which it was criticized.[652][653]

Throughout his career, James has taken a unique approach to his NBA contracts, usually opting to sign shorter-term deals in order to maximize his earnings potential and flexibility;[116][654][655] in 2006, James and the Cavaliers negotiated a three-year, $60 million contract extension instead of the four-year maximum as it allotted him the option of seeking a new contract worth more money as an unrestricted free agent following the 2010 season.[656] This move ultimately allowed James, Dwyane Wade, and Chris Bosh to sign together with the Heat.[657] During the 2011 NBA lockout, James received contract offers to play professional football from the Dallas Cowboys and Seattle Seahawks,[658] which he gave serious consideration to and even began training with it in mind.[659] During his second stint in Cleveland, based on a negotiation strategy devised by NBA agent Mark Termini, who worked with Paul and specialized in contract negotiation and construction,[660] James began re-signing[661][662] on new contracts after each season in order to take advantage of higher salaries resulting from the NBA's rising salary cap.[175] In 2016, he signed with the Cavaliers on a three-year deal,[663] becoming the highest-paid player in the league for the first time in his career.[664]
